qns.entity.memory.memory module

class qns.entity.memory.memory.QuantumMemory(name: str, **kwargs: Unpack[QuantumMemoryInitKwargs])[source]

Bases: Entity

Quantum memory stores qubits or entangled pairs

It has two modes:

Synchronous mode, users can use the read and write function to operate the memory directly without delay Asynchronous mode, users can use events to operate memories asynchronously

allocate(path_id: int, path_direction: PathDirection, *, ch_name: str, n=1) → list[int][source]

Allocate n qubits to a given path ID.

This method searches for n qubits that have not yet been allocated (i.e., path_id is None), assigns them the provided path_id, and returns their addresses.

Parameters:

  • path_id – The identifier of the entanglement path to which the memory qubit will be allocated.

  • ch_name – The name of the quantum channel to which the memory qubit is assigned.

  • path_direction – The end of the path to which the qubit allocated qubit points. This is typically either the source or the destination of the path (LEFT/RIGHT).

Returns:

List of qubit addresses.

Raises:

OverflowError - insufficient unallocated qubits. –

assign(ch: QuantumChannel, n=1) → list[int][source]

Assign n qubits to a particular quantum channel.

This is only used at topology creation time.

Returns:

List of qubit addresses.

Raises:

OverflowError - insufficient unassigned qubits. –

capacity

Memory capacity, i.e. how many qubits can be stored. Each qubit would have an address in [0, capacity).

clear() → None[source]

Clear all qubits in the memory.

property count: int

Return the quantity of stored qubits.

deallocate(*addrs: int) → None[source]

Deallocate one or more qubits from any assigned path.

This method finds the memory qubit with the given address and clears its path assignment (i.e., resets its path_id to None). It does not modify the quantum state or remove the qubit from memory.

decohere_qubit(qubit: MemoryQubit, qm: QuantumModel)[source]

Mark the BaseEntanglement quantum model associated with a qubit as decohered. This is invoked through decoherence event from _schedule_decohere.

  1. Check whether the EPR pair still exists in memory via self.read(key=qm). - If the qubit was already released via swap/purify, it is safely ignored. - If the qubit was re-entangled, it would be associated with a different quantum model

    and would not be found via self.read(key=qm).

  2. If the EPR is still present, set the qubit to RELEASE state, and then schedule a QubitDecoheredEvent to inform the link layer.

Parameters:

  • qubit – The memory qubit that has reached its decoherence time.

  • qm – The assocated quantum model, which must also be an instance of BaseEntanglement.

decoherence_delay

Inverse of decoherence_rate, i.e. duration between EPR creation time and decoherence time in seconds.

delay

Read/write delay, only applicable to async access.

find(predicate: Callable[[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel | None], bool]) → Iterator[tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel | None]][source]
find(predicate: Callable[[MemoryQubit, BaseEntanglement], bool], *, has_epr: Literal[True]) → Iterator[tuple[MemoryQubit, BaseEntanglement]]
get(key: int | QuantumModel | str, *, must: None = None) → tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel | None] | None[source]
get(key: int | QuantumModel | str, *, must: Literal[True]) → tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel | None]
get_channel_qubits(ch_name: str) → list[tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel | None]][source]

Retrieve all memory qubits associated with a specific quantum channel.

This method returns all memory qubits that are linked to the given quantum channel name, regardless of their state or usage.

Parameters:

ch_name (str) – The name of the quantum channel to filter qubits by.

Returns:

A list of memory qubits (along with their QuantumModel) that are bound to the specified quantum channel.

Return type:

List[Tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel]]

handle(event: Event) → None[source]

handle is called to process an receiving Event.

Parameters:

event (qns.simulator.event.Event) – the event that send to this entity

is_full() → bool[source]

Check whether the memory is full

node: QNode | None

QNode that owns this memory.

This is assigned by QNode.set_memory().

pending_decohere_events: dict[str, Event]

Table of pending decoherence events. Key is BaseEntanglement.name. Value is the decohere event, which should be uncanceled and unexpired.

read(key: int | QuantumModel | str, *, destructive=True, must: None = None) → tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel] | None[source]
read(key: int | QuantumModel | str, *, destructive=True, must: Literal[True]) → tuple[MemoryQubit, QuantumModel]
unassign(*addrs: int) → None[source]

Unassign one or more qubits from any quantum channel.

update(old_qm: str, new_qm: QuantumModel) → bool[source]

Update the data of a stored qubit without resetting its coherence time.

This method replaces an existing quantum model in memory with a new one, preserving the original decoherence schedule. The old decoherence event is canceled and replaced with a new event for the updated model, but at the same decoherence time.

Parameters:

  • old_qm (str) – The name of the existing QuantumModel to be replaced.

  • new_qm (QuantumModel) – The new QuantumModel instance to store in its place.

Returns:

True if the update was successful, False if old_qm was not found

(e.g., already decohered or removed).

Return type:

bool

Notes

  • If old_qm is not found in memory but a pending decoherence event still exists,

that event is canceled and removed to avoid inconsistency. - This method does not modify the coherence time or reschedule it—only updates the stored quantum model while maintaining timing integrity.

write(qm: QuantumModel, *, path_id: int | None = None, address: int | None = None, key: str | None = None) → MemoryQubit | None[source]

Store a quantum model (e.g., a qubit or an entangled pair) in memory.

  1. Find an unused memory slot that satisfies optional constraints.

  2. Store and provided quantum model.

  3. Schedule a decoherence event based on the memory’s decoherence rate.

Parameters:

  • qm – The quantum model to store (e.g., an entangled pair).

  • path_id – Constrain by MemoryQubit.path_id field (set by allocate).

  • address – Constrain by qubit address.

  • key – Constrain by MemoryQubit.active field (set in LinkLayer reservation).

Returns:

Qubit where the quantum model was stored, or None if no storage available.

qns.entity.memory.memory_qubit module

class qns.entity.memory.memory_qubit.MemoryQubit(addr: int)[source]

Bases: object

An addressable qubit in memory, with a lifecycle.

active: str | None

Reservation key if qubit is reserved for entanglement, None otherwise

addr

Address index in QuantumMemory.

allocate(path_id: int, path_direction: PathDirection | None = None) → None[source]
assign(ch: QuantumChannel) → None[source]
deallocate() → None[source]
path_direction: PathDirection | None

Optional end of the path to which the allocated qubit points to (weak solution to avoid loops)

path_id: int | None

Optional path ID to which qubit is allocated

purif_rounds

Number of purification rounds currently completed by the EPR stored on this qubit

qchannel: QuantumChannel | None

qchannel to which qubit is assigned to (currently only at topology creation time)

reset_state() → None[source]

Reset state to RAW and clear associated fields.

property state: QubitState
unassign() → None[source]
class qns.entity.memory.memory_qubit.PathDirection(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

LEFT = 1
RIGHT = 2
class qns.entity.memory.memory_qubit.QubitState(value)[source]

Bases: Enum

ACTIVE = 2

The link layer has started a reservation on the qubit as the primary node. qubit.active contains the reservation key.

ELIGIBLE = 8

Qubit has completed the required rounds of purification and ready for swapping or end-to-end consumption.

This state is set on the qubit only if own node has a swapping rank no less than the other node in the entanglement.

ENTANGLED0 = 4

Qubit is half of an elementary entanglement delivered from link layer. QubitEntangledEvent has not been processed by forwarder.

ENTANGLED1 = 5

Qubit is half of an elementary entanglement delivered from link layer. QubitEntangledEvent has been processed by forwarder.

PENDING = 7

The forwarder has initiated purification of the qubit with its partner on a segment. qubit.qubit_rounds indicates how many purification rounds have been completed, excluding the current round.

PURIF = 6

Qubit is used by forwarder for zero or more rounds of purification. qubit.qubit_rounds indicates how many purification rounds have been completed.

This state is set on the qubit at both primary and secondary node of a purification segment, but only the primary node is permitted to initiate purification.

RAW = 1

Qubit is unused.

RELEASE = 9

Qubit is not used by the forwarder. The link layer may generate a new elementary entanglement into this qubit.

RESERVED = 3

Qubit is part of a reservation in link layer and a remote qubit has been found. qubit.active contains the reservation key.

This state is set on the qubit at both primary and secondary node of the reservation.

class qns.entity.memory.QuantumMemory(name: str, **kwargs: Unpack[QuantumMemoryInitKwargs])[source]

Bases: Entity

Quantum memory stores qubits or entangled pairs

It has two modes:

Synchronous mode, users can use the read and write function to operate the memory directly without delay Asynchronous mode, users can use events to operate memories asynchronously

allocate(path_id: int, path_direction: PathDirection, *, ch_name: str, n=1) → list[int][source]

Allocate n qubits to a given path ID.

This method searches for n qubits that have not yet been allocated (i.e., path_id is None), assigns them the provided path_id, and returns their addresses.

Parameters:

  • path_id – The identifier of the entanglement path to which the memory qubit will be allocated.

  • ch_name – The name of the quantum channel to which the memory qubit is assigned.

  • path_direction – The end of the path to which the qubit allocated qubit points. This is typically either the source or the destination of the path (LEFT/RIGHT).

Returns:

List of qubit addresses.

Raises:

OverflowError - insufficient unallocated qubits. –

decohere_qubit(qubit: MemoryQubit, qm: QuantumModel)[source]

Mark the BaseEntanglement quantum model associated with a qubit as decohered. This is invoked through decoherence event from _schedule_decohere.

  1. Check whether the EPR pair still exists in memory via self.read(key=qm). - If the qubit was already released via swap/purify, it is safely ignored. - If the qubit was re-entangled, it would be associated with a different quantum model

    and would not be found via self.read(key=qm).

  2. If the EPR is still present, set the qubit to RELEASE state, and then schedule a QubitDecoheredEvent to inform the link layer.

Parameters:

  • qubit – The memory qubit that has reached its decoherence time.

  • qm – The assocated quantum model, which must also be an instance of BaseEntanglement.

decoherence_delay

Inverse of decoherence_rate, i.e. duration between EPR creation time and decoherence time in seconds.

delay

Read/write delay, only applicable to async access.

update(old_qm: str, new_qm: QuantumModel) → bool[source]

Update the data of a stored qubit without resetting its coherence time.

This method replaces an existing quantum model in memory with a new one, preserving the original decoherence schedule. The old decoherence event is canceled and replaced with a new event for the updated model, but at the same decoherence time.

Parameters:

  • old_qm (str) – The name of the existing QuantumModel to be replaced.

  • new_qm (QuantumModel) – The new QuantumModel instance to store in its place.

Returns:

True if the update was successful, False if old_qm was not found

(e.g., already decohered or removed).

Return type:

bool

Notes

  • If old_qm is not found in memory but a pending decoherence event still exists,

that event is canceled and removed to avoid inconsistency. - This method does not modify the coherence time or reschedule it—only updates the stored quantum model while maintaining timing integrity.

write(qm: QuantumModel, *, path_id: int | None = None, address: int | None = None, key: str | None = None) → MemoryQubit | None[source]

Store a quantum model (e.g., a qubit or an entangled pair) in memory.

  1. Find an unused memory slot that satisfies optional constraints.

  2. Store and provided quantum model.

  3. Schedule a decoherence event based on the memory’s decoherence rate.

Parameters:

  • qm – The quantum model to store (e.g., an entangled pair).

  • path_id – Constrain by MemoryQubit.path_id field (set by allocate).

  • address – Constrain by qubit address.

  • key – Constrain by MemoryQubit.active field (set in LinkLayer reservation).

Returns:

Qubit where the quantum model was stored, or None if no storage available.
